description: A lowly utility worker is called to the future by a mysterious radio signal, he must leave his dying wife to embark on a journey that will force him to face his deepest fears in an attempt to change the fabric of reality and save humankind from its greatest environmental crisis yet.

reviews.text: Kodi Smit-McPhee single-handedly carries on his back a film that seems dead from the start, even with its ambitious premise.He does a fine job as the lead, but even he isn't able to bring life to a story that gets stuck between what it intends and what it ultimately delivers.

Not a great film but not the worst either.Kodi Smit-McPhee is hard to look at physically, there is something approaching uncanny valley about his facial structure; perhaps it’s the wide-set eyes and androgynous appearance. Aside, his acting is inconsistently believable, but it’s always nice to see a rock solid Ryan Kwanten even if it’s in a supporting role, and Ryan provides some viewer relief along the ride.The plot, whilst enticing as a concept, feels pedestrian at times, and makes “getting to the end” feel like a chore. There are redeeming qualities; the sets are cool and overall production effort is reassuring, and the ambition is commendable. If you’re fan of science fiction, particularly time travel and dystopias, this is worth a try, but keep your expectations low.

Most of today's SciFi is dull beyond belief. This was different. Sure, the time-travel to save the world thing has been done many times before, but this was woven around a fairly compelling personal story, some wild exaggerations of human impact on the planet and a mixture of good and bad acting (along with some terrible science!). All in all it seemed like a very good local stage drama, flaws, drama and all. The ending was a decent one too. Maybe what I enjoyed most of all was an honest attempt to tell a good SciFi story without the preachy PC whining that's embedded a lot of new content by default. A solid 9 for creativity and focus on entertainment.
